title: Smart Pill Dispenser — STM32-Based Medication Management System

sections.title: Project Background
sections.content: The Smart Pill Dispenser was focused on improving medication management in both hospital and home-care environments. It addresses common medication errors caused by forgetfulness, manual scheduling, and human oversight, especially among elderly users and busy healthcare staff. The system is built using an STM32 microcontroller and automates pill dispensing at scheduled times while confirming dispensing activity through sensors.

sections.title: Problem
sections.content: Many patients, particularly elderly users, forget to take medication or accidentally take it more than once. In hospital settings, manual medication handling increases staff workload and raises the risk of missed or incorrect doses during busy routines.

sections.title: Solution
sections.content: The system automates medication dispensing by releasing pills at predefined times and verifying the dispensing process using sensors. This reduces reliance on memory and manual handling, improving medication safety and consistency. In normal mode, the dispenser runs its scheduled cycles automatically, while configuration mode (unlocked via RFID and keypad input) is used by authorised staff to adjust or update medication timings before returning to normal operation.

sections.title: My Role
items: Programmed STM32 microcontroller using Embedded C++.
Integrated RTC, RFID, IR sensor, and servo motor.
Debugged electrical wiring and firmware issues.
Tested system reliability and dispensing accuracy.

sections.alt: System block diagram of the smart pill dispenser
sections.caption: Block diagram showing the STM32 microcontroller, input sensors, user interfaces, and output devices

sections.title: System Flow & Operation
items: System starts in normal operating mode after power-up.
Authorised staff can enter configuration mode using RFID authentication.
In configuration mode, the keypad is used to set or update medication schedules.
Configuration options and system status are shown on the OLED display.
RTC continuously keeps track of the current time.
When a scheduled dispensing time is reached, the STM32 triggers the dispensing process.
Servo motor rotates to release a single pill.
IR sensor confirms whether a pill has been successfully dispensed.
PIR sensor detects user presence near the dispenser during operation.
System status, alerts, and feedback are displayed on the OLED and LCD screens.
After dispensing, the system returns to normal mode and waits for the next scheduled cycle.

sections.title: Outcomes
content: Our project was made possible by developing an automated pill dispensing system using STM32 firmware and Embedded C++, integrating RTC scheduling, servo control, and IR/PIR sensor feedback to ensure accurate and reliable dispensing. This design reduced missed or double doses during testing and improved overall system safety through RFID-based configuration access that prevented unauthorised changes. The system was validated through repeated end-to-end prototype testing, demonstrating stable operation across multiple dispensing cycles.

sections.title: Technical Summary
items: Microcontroller: STM32F103RB
Programming Language: Embedded C++
Sensors: IR sensor, PIR sensor
Actuator: Servo motor
Modules: RFID RC522, RTC DS3231
Displays: OLED (SSD1306), LCD
Application Area: Healthcare automation

title: IoT-Based Supermarket Self-Checkout System
role: IoT Systems Developer | Embedded & Software Engineer

sections.title: Project Background
sections.content: This project is an IoT-based Supermarket Self-Checkout System designed to improve shopping efficiency by allowing customers to independently scan items, manage purchases, and complete payments. The system supports both in-store and online purchases, including membership authentication, QR code generation for in-store pickup, and secure payment handling.

sections.title: Problem
sections.content: Traditional supermarket checkout systems often result in long queues, high manpower dependency, and inefficient transitions between in-store and online shopping workflows, negatively impacting customer experience during peak hours.

sections.title: Solution
sections.content: A unified self-checkout solution was developed using a Raspberry Pi as the central controller, integrating Picamera-based barcode scanning, RFID authentication, cart management, and payment processing. In addition to in-store checkout, the system includes an online shopping website where users can browse products, add items to a cart, and place orders remotely. Product information, user/cart data, and orders are stored and managed in a MariaDB database. For online pickup orders, the system generates a QR code containing an Order ID to enable fast in-store pickup verification. Power management logic was implemented to reduce energy consumption by dynamically switching between low and high power operating modes.

sections.title: Use Case Diagram
sections.alt: Use case diagram for supermarket self-checkout system
sections.caption: Use case diagram illustrating interactions between in-store customers, online customers, payment gateway, and backend systems

sections.title: Use Case Diagram Explanation
sections.content:
The use case diagram illustrates the functional interactions between different actors and the supermarket self-checkout system. In-store customers initialize the system, scan items using a camera, and complete payments. The scanning workflow includes continuous item verification against the product database, followed by cart total calculation and checkout confirmation. Optional membership authentication is performed using RFID, extending the payment process with additional validation steps.

Online customers interact with the system through a website to browse products, add items to the cart, and complete checkout remotely. The website communicates with a MariaDB database to retrieve product details and store cart/order information. For online pickup purchases, the system generates a QR code containing an Order ID, which is scanned during in-store pickup for verification. The payment gateway supports payment methods such as ATM card, PayWave/RFID, and Visa, while backend services handle authentication, item validation, and order summary generation.

sections.title: Hardware & Interface Architecture
sections.caption: Hardware interface architecture showing sensors, input devices, and output peripherals connected to the Raspberry Pi

sections.title: Hardware Architecture Explanation
sections.content:
The hardware architecture is centered around a Raspberry Pi development board, which serves as the main controller for all system operations. A camera module connected via the CSI port performs barcode scanning for item identification. An RFID reader interfaced through GPIO and SPI pins enables membership authentication, while a keypad connected to GPIO pins allows user input for menu navigation and checkout control.

An ultrasonic sensor connected to GPIO pins is used to detect object presence and system interaction states. Output devices include an LCD connected through the I2C interface for displaying menus, item details, and payment information, as well as a buzzer connected to a GPIO pin to provide audio feedback during authentication and system events. This modular hardware design ensures reliable real-time interaction between sensors, user interfaces, and backend software components.

sections.title: System Flow & Operation
items: System powers on and displays the main menu on the LCD interface
User initiates checkout and begins scanning items using the camera
Scanned items are validated against the product database and added to the cart
System continuously updates and displays the cumulative total
User optionally performs RFID-based membership authentication
Payment is processed securely through the payment system
For online orders, a QR code is generated and scanned during in-store pickup verification
System transitions between high and low power modes based on activity state

sections.title: Outcomes
sections.content: The system was successfully implemented based on a structured requirements specification covering item scanning, authentication, payment workflows, online ordering with QR-based pickup verification, and dynamic power management. Functional testing validated end-to-end operation across in-store and online scenarios, demonstrating reliable system behavior and effective energy-saving transitions between Low Power Mode and High Power Mode.

sections.title: Key Functional Features
items: System startup and main menu display on LCD with keypad navigation
In-store item scanning using camera-based barcode detection
Real-time cart management and cumulative price calculation
Optional member authentication using RFID with buzzer feedback
Secure in-store payment processing
Online shopping support with QR code generation for in-store pickup verification
Low Power Mode (LPM): Activated when the user exits the system or when no high-power activity is detected for a defined inactivity period to conserve energy
High Power Mode (HPM): Activated during scanning, database lookup, cart updates, authentication, payment processing, and QR code generation

sections.title: Technical Summary
items: Controller: Raspberry Pi
Programming Language: Python
Online Platform: Website (Online Shopping)
Database: MariaDB (Products, Cart, Orders)
Item Detection: Camera-based Barcode Scanning
Authentication Module: RFID Reader
Presence Detection: Ultrasonic Sensor
User Interface: LCD Display (I2C), Keypad
Feedback Device: Buzzer
Order Verification: QR Code Generation
Power Management: Low Power Mode (LPM), High Power Mode (HPM)
Application Area: Smart Retail & IoT Automation

title: StockPulse – Stock Trading & Market Analysis Platform
heroAlt: StockPulse stock trading and market analysis platform

sections.title: At a Glance
sections.content: A web-based stock trading simulation platform that allows users to practise buying and selling stocks using virtual funds, with an emphasis on clear interaction flow and visual feedback.

sections.title: Platform Overview
sections.caption: Core interfaces including portfolio overview, stock detail view, buy/sell workflow, and watchlist.

sections.title: Interface & Interaction Design
sections.content: The platform is structured around a clear navigation flow that guides users through portfolio viewing, stock exploration, and trade execution. Visual hierarchy and motion cues are used to help users understand state changes and transitions without overwhelming them, making the system approachable even for users new to stock trading concepts.

sections.title: Stock Exploration
sections.caption: Stock detail page displaying pricing data, visual indicators, and available actions.

sections.title: Stock Data Presentation
sections.content: Stock information is presented using a combination of numeric values and visual indicators such as price ranges and recommendation bars. These visual elements help users quickly interpret market conditions and trends without requiring prior financial knowledge.

sections.title: Buy & Sell Workflow
sections.caption: Buy and sell interface allowing users to select trade action and quantity.

sections.title: Trade Interaction Flow
sections.content: The buy and sell workflow is intentionally constrained to reduce user error. Animated feedback and validation messages are used to confirm successful actions and to alert users when invalid operations occur, such as insufficient funds or stock quantity.

sections.title: Watchlist & Tracking
sections.caption: Watchlist displaying tracked stocks and price changes.

sections.title: Tracking & Review
sections.content: The watchlist and transaction history features allow users to monitor selected stocks and review past actions. These sections support reflection and learning by making trading behaviour visible and easy to revisit.

sections.title: My Role
items: Implemented frontend animations and interaction effects across the platform
Added animated sign-out interaction for clear session feedback
Enhanced page transitions to improve navigation continuity
Ensured animations were lightweight and non-intrusive

Interaction Design: UI Animations & Transitions
Trading Mode: Paper Trading (Virtual Funds)
